channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Government loses Abu Qatada appeal
item.description: Home Secretary Theresa May loses her appeal against a ruling preventing the deportation of radical cleric Abu Qatada.

item.title: Pair jailed for selling Sun stories
item.description: A former prison worker is jailed for selling information about one of James Bulger's killer to the Sun, as an ex-PC is also jailed for a similar offence.

item.title: Tributes paid to dog attack girl
item.description: Tributes are paid to a 14-year-old girl who died after she was attacked by a pack of "out of control" dogs at a house in Greater Manchester.

item.title: Miliband feared 'being distraction'
item.description: David Miliband says he believes his move to work in the US will allow his brother to lead Labour against the coalition in an "uninhibited way".

item.title: Banks told to raise an extra £25bn
item.description: Major UK banks must raise a total of £25bn in extra capital by the end of 2013 to guard against potential losses, the Bank of England (BoE) says.

item.title: Care home worker held over murder
item.description: A member of staff at a Manchester care home is arrested on suspicion of murder following the death of a resident.

item.title: Prudential fined £30m over AIA bid
item.description: Insurance giant Prudential has been fined £30m by regulators over its 2010 bid to buy AIA, an Asian subsidiary of US insurer AIG.

item.title: Bank of Cyprus head Kypri 'sacked'
item.description: The chief executive of the Bank of Cyprus has been sacked, reportedly at the behest of the country's international lenders.

item.title: Two trapped after Devon landslip
item.description: Two people, including a pregnant woman, are believed to be trapped on a Devon beach following a landslide.

item.title: Cold weather disruption continues
item.description: Severe weather continues to cause disruption across parts of the UK, as forecasters warn the cold temperatures will last until mid-April.

item.title: Figures confirm UK economy shrinking
item.description: The UK economy contracted by 0.3% in the fourth quarter of 2012, official figures show, confirming previous estimates.

item.title: Dionne Warwick files for bankruptcy
item.description: Walk On By singer Dionne Warwick files for bankruptcy in the US after amounting debts of almost $10 million (£6.6 million) in taxes.

item.title: Beaches fall below safety standards
item.description: The number of beaches failing to meet minimum standards for water quality rises after 2012's wet summer, the Marine Conservation Society report.

item.title: VIDEO: King-size baby George born at 15lbs
item.description: The second largest baby born naturally in the UK - weighing in at 15 pounds and 7 ounces is born to a couple from Cheltenham.

item.title: Pope Francis shuns grand residence
item.description: Pope Francis breaks with tradition and refuses to move into a palatial apartment at the top of the Apostolic Palace in the Vatican.

item.title: Lloyd's of London back in profit
item.description: Insurance market Lloyd's of London is back in profit, despite paying one of the biggest claims in its history after Superstorm Sandy.

item.title: Brics nations mull development bank
item.description: Leaders of the Brics nations - Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa - are meeting to discuss the formation of a new development bank.

item.title: Homes bonus 'inadequately monitored'
item.description: The government is not "adequately" monitoring the spending of its £1.3bn New Homes Bonus, aimed at boosting housebuilding, Whitehall's spending watchdog warns.

item.title: NHS emergency set-up unclear, say MPs
item.description: The government's NHS reforms in England mean it is "not clear who will be in charge in the event of a health emergency", MPs warn.

item.title: Parental 'problem behaviour guide'
item.description: A watchdog issues guidelines to help parents distinguish naughtiness from more worrying behaviour in their children that may need medical intervention.

item.title: No more covering up errors, NHS told
item.description: The NHS will have a legal duty to be honest about mistakes as part of an overhaul of the system in the wake of the Stafford Hospital scandal.

item.title: Warning of 'teacher shortage crisis'
item.description: Pupils in England could be taught in bigger classes and by unqualified staff, as schools will need an extra 15,000 teachers, Labour claims.

item.title: MSPs debate Post-16 education plan
item.description: MSPs are due to debate controversial Scottish government plans to change the way colleges and universities are run.

item.title: Anti-cyber threat centre launched
item.description: A new initiative to share information on cyber threats between businesses and government is launched.

item.title: Campaigners warn on Google Glass use
item.description: Google Glass and other augmented reality gadgets risk creating a world in which privacy is impossible, warn campaigners.

item.title: Fracking 'linked to Oklahoma quake'
item.description: Scientists studying a 2011 earthquake in the US state of Oklahoma - the largest ever in the state - say hydraulic fracturing wastewater was to blame.

item.title: Darwin letters reveal emotional side
item.description: A collection of previously unpublished letters by Charles Darwin reveal a highly emotional side to the naturalist.

item.title: Shaw slates music finance 'barrier'
item.description: Singer Sandie Shaw criticises the music industry for favouring public school musicians, saying finance is "the biggest barrier for emerging artists".

item.title: BBC stops Sri Lanka broadcasts
item.description: The BBC halts radio news services provided to Sri Lanka's state broadcaster because of 'continued interruption and interference' in its programming.

item.title: Why are the French drinking less wine?
item.description: Does the seemingly perpetual decline in consumption of France's national drink symbolise a corresponding decline in French civilisation?

item.title: Who still collects first day covers?
item.description: Stamps celebrating the 50 years of Doctor Who are the latest in a series of special anniversary stamps. Who collects first day covers?

item.title: England must improve, says Flower
item.description: Coach Andy Flower says England must improve to beat Australia in the two Ashes series this year.

item.title: Two National fancies to miss Aintree
item.description: Grand National contenders Prince De Beauchene and Beshabar are out of the big race on 6 April with injuries.

item.title: England fate in our hands - Hodgson
item.description: England manager Roy Hodgson says his side's World Cup destiny is still in their hands despite a 1-1 draw against Montenegro.

item.title: Ding succumbs to Hawkins in China
item.description: Home favourite Ding Junhui becomes the latest top player to make an early exit from the China Open.

item.title: Djokovic stunned by Haas in Miami
item.description: World number one Novak Djokovic suffers a shock defeat by Tommy Haas in the fourth round of the Sony Open.

item.title: Shop fire collapse shuts busy road
item.description: One of the main routes into Birmingham is expected to remain shut for the rest of the day after a severe fire at a shop.

item.title: Tube drivers vote to go on strike
item.description: Tube drivers on the Jubilee Line are planning two 24-hour strikes in a row over working conditions and claims of bullying.

item.title: Snow and ice bring travel disruption
item.description: Travel is disrupted as further snow hits many parts of Scotland, and police warn that many road surfaces remain icy.

item.title: Teachers 'support' strike action
item.description: Members of Scotland's largest teaching union have said they are willing to strike in a row over pensions.

item.title: Remote areas still deep in snow
item.description: The severe weather conditions are still having an impact across many parts of Northern Ireland.

item.title: Tax decision in 2014 'disappointing'
item.description: The NI Independent Retail Trade Association says the government's delay on a decision to devolve corporation tax to Stormont is deeply disappointing.

item.title: Low vaccine fear in measles epidemic
item.description: Health officials say they are disappointed in the uptake of the vaccines at the centre of a measles epidemic said to be spreading at an "alarming rate".

item.title: Ambulance targets missed again
item.description: Wales' ambulances missed a response-time target for life-threatening calls for the ninth consecutive month, Welsh government figures have shown.

item.title: Somalia refugees 'abused and raped'
item.description: Refugees fleeing famine and conflict within Somalia suffer sexual violence and other abuse in camps in the capital, says Human Rights Watch.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius' brother in court
item.description: The brother of South African athletics star Oscar Pistorius, who is charged with murder, appears in court over a motorcyclist's death in a road accident in 2008.

item.title: N Korea cuts South military hotline
item.description: North Korea says it is cutting a military hotline with South Korea, amid escalating rhetoric and high tension on the peninsula.

item.title: Suu Kyi attends Burma army parade
item.description: Burma marks its Armed Forces Day with a military parade, with opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi in attendance for the first time.

item.title: NGO fears as Russian raids multiply
item.description: Senior EU officials voice concern as checks by Russian tax inspectors on foreign-funded non-governmental organisations multiply.

item.title: Berlin Wall section removed amid row
item.description: Parts of a historic stretch of the Berlin Wall marked for property development are removed amid heavy police presence despite angry protests.

item.title: Rio 2016 stadium indefinitely closed
item.description: A stadium in Rio de Janeiro, due to be used for the 2016 Olympics, is closed indefinitely because of problems with its roof.

item.title: Workers' rights for maids in Brazil
item.description: Brazilian senators pass a bill giving domestic servants equal rights to other workers for the first time.

item.title: Egypt prosecutor sacking overturned
item.description: An Egyptian appeals court reinstates the prosecutor general, whose sacking by President Mohammed Morsi had angered senior judges.

item.title: Opposition takes Syria summit seat
item.description: Syria's opposition National Coalition takes the official seat of the country at the start of a two-day Arab League summit in Qatar.

item.title: US justices to hear second gay case
item.description: The US Supreme Court is to review whether to strike down a law denying federal benefits to same-sex couples, a day after weighing a gay marriage ban.

item.title: US state gets toughest abortion law
item.description: North Dakota bans abortion once a foetal heartbeat can be detected - as early as six weeks - in the most restrictive law of its kind in the US.

item.title: In pictures: Losing Ground
item.description: Communities in Cambodia fight for their right to land

item.title: Day in pictures: 26 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 26 March

item.title: In pictures: Shifting Perspectives
item.description: Representation of people with Down’s syndrome

item.title: Day in pictures: 25 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 25 March

item.title: In Pictures: Rowena Cade's theatre
item.description: The Minack Theatre prepares for its new season

item.title: In pictures: Earth Hour around the world
item.description: Images from around the world of Earth Hour

item.title: Week in pictures: 16-22 March 2013
item.description: A selection of the best photos from the news

item.title: Day in pictures: 22 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 22 March

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The health secretary has set out the government's response to the Stafford Hospital inquiry.

item.title: VIDEO: Is jet stream to blame for bad weather?
item.description: The weather this spring is in contrast to that of last March, the third warmest on record, when temperatures were in the 70s.

item.title: VIDEO: Inside the Kings Cross signal box
item.description: Richard Westcott is given a tour of the signal box at Kings Cross, one of the busiest railway stations in Britain.

item.title: VIDEO: HMS Edinburgh's final home voyage
item.description: The last of the Navy's Type 42 destroyer is making its final home voyage home to Portsmouth before it is decommissioned.

item.title: VIDEO: Tributes to teen 'killed by dogs'
item.description: Friends of a 14-year-old girl thought to have been killed by a pack of dogs have been paying tribute to the teenager, and laying flowers at the scene of her death.

item.title: VIDEO: Snow misery spreads across Europe
item.description: Unseasonably cold weather and freak blizzards are continuing to cause chaos across many parts of Europe.

item.title: VIDEO: Knox to fight 'wrongful' allegations
item.description: US student Amanda Knox has said she will fight to clear her name after an Italian court overturned her acquittal for killing Briton Meredith Kercher.

item.title: AUDIO: Care regulator 'ignored concerns'
item.description: A senior figure at a health regulator has accused it of ignoring concerns about some hospitals in England.

item.title: VIDEO: Six million trees for Queen's Jubilee
item.description: A project to plant six million trees across the UK will finally be completed on Wednesday when Princess Anne plants the final tree at an inner city school.

item.title: The bikes for people who don't cycle
item.description: Is riding around on an electric bike just cheating?

item.title: Did Beeching get it wrong 50 years ago?
item.description: Did Dr Beeching get it wrong 50 years ago?

item.title: The trouble with 'snitches'
item.description: The trouble with using police informants in the US

item.title: Benefit changes: Who will be affected?
item.description: How will you be affected and by how much?

item.title: VIDEO: Why are Colorado's black bears getting bolder?
item.description: Why are Colorado's black bears getting bolder?

item.title: Global migrants: Which are the most wanted professions?
item.description: Try our interactive guide to find the professions in high demand

item.title: Rene Burri in colour
item.description: Noted Magnum photographer's little-known colour shots

item.title: Is pigeon racing cruel?
item.description: Roger Harrabin examines claims pigeon racing is cruel

item.title: Why does Cyprus need capital controls?
item.description: Why Cyprus has brought in capital controls

item.title: Australia PM backs UK monarch role
item.description: Republican and monarch find common ground

item.title: Where England lost their way in Montenegro
item.description: Former defender Danny Mills asks why England lost their way
